posts.cooked:
Given the recent publicity around Phishing, I think it would be good if the device linking procedure required the user to match an emoji or number on the device screen being linked.

This is similar to what Google Messages does, and it’s fairly unobtrusive, but it does make it harder for someone to accidentally link their device.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
as i already said on another topic:

Ability to disable device linking Feature Requests
this specific attack was already mitigated. in general, every act of linking requires active user action, including (at least on Android but i believe that on iOS as well) verifying you’re the owner of the device using the device PIN.

in addition:

Linked devices notification/indicator on main screen UI/UX Feedback
there is now a push notification after a randomised time, reminding a person of a recently linked device. i think this is a good compromise between the desire to inform the user and the wish not to clutter the home screen.

posts.name: Wyatt Childers
posts.cooked:
this specific attack was already mitigated. in general, every act of linking requires active user action, including (at least on Android but i believe that on iOS as well) verifying you’re the owner of the device using the device PIN.

I unlinked my desktop app and then attempted to relink it (both running the respective latest versions of Signal). The prompt that appears is IMO an insufficient mitigation. It’s a blurb of text with the options being “cancel” and “continue.”

Picking the matching emoji (or perhaps entering a number on the screen) is a much stronger mitigation as it requires the local user to actually know information on the attacker’s screen.

posts.name: Wyatt Childers
posts.cooked:
you think that going to settings>linked devices>link new device>put in your device password>scan QR in a screen that says “scan QR to link new device”>confirmation prompt doesn’t make it clear enough you’re linking a new device?

I literally can just go to my phone camera and scan a QR code, it redirects into Signal where it asks for confirmation.

That seems to fail currently if you say “continue.” But, I can’t say whether that’s a bug or a mitigation … because it doesn’t say “Hey, this is a link a device thing!” It’s the exact same confirmation used when you press “Link a new device.”

settings>linked devices>link new device>put in your device password>scan

Also in the the “put in your device password”; well, I have face unlock, so that prompt almost immediately dismisses itself anyways.

Either way, the UX here is clunky.

also how would matching emoji help? the attacker could broadcast the emoji the same way they are broadcasting the QR code. in both cases i’m reacting to a thing that’s on my screen. how is it more secure?

Matching emoji or numbers introduces a confirmation that requires some thought. It’s not something you can “sleep walk” through. Presumably, this is why the majority of software uses “pairing codes” (or the spin on it where you pick an emoji or a number from a list) as opposed to just asking for confirmation.

If the Phone QR Code → “Confirm” button linking process ever “works” (like it looks like it should), then you can very much sleep walk through that.

In an environment where reports like this are coming up within the last month (and I do not see a Signal changelog entry to address it), I really strongly disagree with the claim that “this is mitigated.”

Dark_Arc:

that’s a ridiculously pedantic take.

is it now? phishing is defined by a user trusting something that is not trustworthy and giving it their credentials. just as an example, Google may make their login screen as clever as possible and try to add as many verifications as they can, but still if you go to a website pretending to be Google, put in your username and password and do all the 2FA confirmations, you’ll still get phished.
Have I Been Pwned recently got phished - no one blamed Mailchimp. posts.name: Wyatt Childers
posts.cooked:
Two months ago, Google began warning the Signal Foundation that maintains the private communications platform about Russia’s use of the QR code phishing technique, and Signal last week finished rolling out an update for iOS and Android designed to counter the trick. The new safeguard warns users when they link a new device and checks with them again at a randomized interval a few hours after that device is added to confirm that they still want to share all messages with it. Signal now also requires a form of authentication such as entering a passcode or using FaceID or TouchID on iOS to add a new linked device.

Yeah, that’s a new article for me. Seemingly things are “good enough” now based on that reporting … I still think there’s some merit to making the interaction more well … interactive, but based on commentary so far I’m in the minority, so I’ll just mark this as resolved.

is it now? [etc]

I do still disagree with this take, phishing is a major topic in “security circles.” It’s not about blame, it’s not about fully “solving it” (because it is always user error), it’s about making it harder.

For some definition of “security circles” what you say surely true, but it’s also unhelpful. In a broader industry since, phishing is most definitely a consideration that needs taken seriously.

the most popular messaging software on planet earth doesn’t do it. Discord doesn’t do it. i also think Telegram doesn’t do this, but i don’t use it so i can’t check. the majority it is not.

IIRC I’ve seen Google software authentication (as a whole) and Google Messages (as a device pairing feature) all take this “match the code” approach. Apple Authentication, Android TV, Telegram also does do a device linking code (typically some 6-digit number).

It’s a strategy that’s clearly getting use; so we can debate whether it’s truly a majority approach or not, but it’s a non-insignificant amount of software using such an approach.
